intro: Abarema mindanaensis, commonly known as the Mindanao acacia, is a flowering plant native to the Philippines. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its leguminous properties and often compound leaves. The plant typically features bipinnate leaves and produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in racemose inflorescences. It is often found in open woodland and secondary forest habitats. Its seeds are encased in elongated pods, which contribute to its ecological role in soil nitrogen fixation.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abarema mindanaensis is primarily native to the Philippines, specifically the island of Mindanao. It is found in the lowland and montane rainforests of this region. The plant thrives in humid, shaded environments with well-drained soil. It is commonly encountered in the eastern part of Mindanao, particularly in the provinces of Davao and Bukidnon. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endemic species in its native habitat.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abarema mindanaensis was mainly introduced to the Philippines. It is commonly found in the lowland areas of Mindanao. This plant thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It is often used in ornamental gardening due to its attractive foliage. Its distribution is limited to specific regions where the environmental conditions are suitable.
